message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of hypertension and smoking, both of which are risk factors for aortic stenosis. Weak peripheral pulses can also be a sign of aortic stenosis. The cardiac exam may reveal a systolic ejection murmur heard best at the right second intercostal space, which is characteristic of aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and smoking history suggest a cardiovascular cause. Weak peripheral pulses indicate aortic stenosis, which causes the narrowing of the aortic valve opening and reduced blood flow from the heart. The cardiac examination findings of a systolic murmur that radiates to the carotids and a weak S2 further support the diagnosis of aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's past history of hypertension, smoking, and symptoms suggest the most likely diagnosis is aortic stenosis. The weak peripheral pulses also support this diagnosis. The cardiac examination showing a harsh systolic ejection murmur that radiates to the carotids and is loudest at the 2nd right intercostal space further supports the diagnosis of aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The weak peripheral pulses and systolic ejection murmur suggest aortic stenosis. Mitral regurgitation would present with a holosystolic murmur, tricuspid stenosis with a diastolic murmur, and aortic regurgitation with a diastolic murmur and bounding pulses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, history of hypertension and smoking, and weak peripheral pulses suggest aortic stenosis. The cardiac exam is not provided, but it may show a systolic ejection murmur and a narrow pulse pressure. Mitral regurgitation and tricuspid stenosis would not present with weak peripheral pulses, and aortic regurgitation would present with bounding peripheral pulses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, history of smoking, and weak peripheral pulses suggest aortic stenosis, which can cause exertional dyspnea and dizziness. The cardiac examination will likely show a systolic ejection murmur at the aortic area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The weak peripheral pulses and the cardiac examination suggest aortic stenosis. Mitral regurgitation would have a holosystolic murmur heard at the apex, while tricuspid stenosis and aortic regurgitation would have different findings on physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cardiac examination shows a systolic ejection murmur and weak peripheral pulses, which are suggestive of aortic stenosis. Mitral regurgitation and tricuspid stenosis are less likely to present with exertional dyspnea and dizziness, and aortic regurgitation typically presents with a diastolic murmur. The patient’s history of smoking and hypertension also raise the suspicion for aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hypertension and a history of smoking, which increases the risk of aortic stenosis. Weak peripheral pulses, increased exertional dyspnea, and dizziness suggest aortic stenosis. The cardiac examination may reveal a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard at the right upper sternal border, which is characteristic of aortic stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of hypertension and smoking, both of which are risk factors for aortic stenosis. The weak peripheral pulses are also suggestive of aortic stenosis. The cardiac examination would reveal a harsh systolic ejection murmur, which is characteristic of aortic stenosis.
